selected_quotes: Here's the journal paper on neural substrates for jaw / tongue muscle coordination #neuroscience
@AChirinosPadron: Compleja operación de neuronas evita que te muerdas la lengua cuando masticas.
Compleja operación de neuronas evita que te muerdas la lengua cuando masticas.

citation.abstract: Feeding behaviors require intricately coordinated activation among the muscles of the jaw, tongue, and face, but the neural anatomical substrates underlying such coordination remain unclear. Here we investigate whether the premotor circuitry of jaw and tongue motoneurons contain elements for coordination. Using a modified monosynaptic rabies virus based transsynaptic tracing strategy, we systematically mapped premotor neurons for the jaw-closing masseter muscle and the tongue-protruding genioglossus muscle. The maps revealed that the two groups of premotor neurons are distributed in regions implicated in rhythmogenesis, descending motor control, and sensory feedback. Importantly, we discovered several premotor connection configurations that are ideally suited for coordinating bilaterally symmetric jaw movements, and for enabling co-activation of specific jaw, tongue, and facial muscles. Our findings suggest that shared premotor neurons that form specific multi-target connections with selected motoneurons are a simple and general solution to the problem of orofacial coordination.
citation.title: Monosynaptic premotor circuit tracing reveals neural substrates for oro-motor coordination

blogs.title: Bite your tongue! You might without this brain circuit
blogs.summary:
Scientists have mapped a brain circuit that keeps mice from biting their tongue every time they chew.

blogs.title: Complex Neural Circuitry Keeps You from Biting Your Tongue
blogs.summary: Researchers map the underlying brain circuitry which keeps mice from biting their tongues as they eat.

news.title: Complex neural circuitry keeps you from biting your tongue
news.summary: Eating, like breathing and sleeping, seems to be a rather basic biological task. Yet chewing requires a complex interplay between the tongue and jaw, with the tongue positioning food between the teeth and then moving out of the way every time the jaw clamp

news.title: Why We Don't Bite Our Tongues When We Chew
news.summary: Chewing is a very complex process, and half the time we are not consciously trying to keep our tongue away from our chompers. So why is it that it is relatively rare to bite your own tongue? New neural mapping may have the answer.
